newsitem.title: USA: Chrysler sets distribution center in South Korea.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler sets distribution center in South Korea.

text.p: Chrysler Corp said Thursday it will expand its presence in South Korea by establishing Chrysler Korea Sales Ltd (CKSL) as a wholly owned subsidiary for importation and distribution.
CKSL, based in Seoul, will be responsible for appointing dealers, setting up a sales and service infrastructure, and coordinating marketing activities, Chrysler said in a statement.

"Chrysler made the decision to take over its distribution to get closer to the market and our consumers and to respond quickly to changing market conditions," said Ronald Gardhouse, general manager for Asia Pacific operations, in a statement.
"The recent reduction of import duties and taxes is an important first step to make the Korean market more attractive and viable for importers like Chrysler," he said.

Chrysler was previously represented by Woosung Department Store, one of 17 companies in the Woosung Group, a South Korean conglomerate. Since its appointment in 1992, Woosung developed a network of 22 dealers throughout South Korea.
Year-to-date, Chrysler has sold more than 1,500 units in South Korea with a calendar year target of 2,500 vehicles. Chrysler sold 1,119 units in 1995.
CKSL expects to sell around 4,000 units in 1997.
CKSL will absorb some of Woosung's existing dealers as well as appoint new main dealers. In addition, CKSL plans to expand and improve the current after-sales network.
Sales of existing inventory will begin in October and imports of 1997 model year vehicles will start in December.
Chrysler currently sells in South Korea three Jeep models -- Wrangler, Cherokee and Grand Cherokee -- and the Chrysler Caravan, Grand Caravan, Vision, Stratus and Neon passenger vehicles.

Separately, Chrysler also said it opened a Southeast Asian regional headquarters in Singapore which will be responsible for business including Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Singapore.
